Act3Scene1.speaker: Banquo
Act3Scene1.text: Thou hast it now—king, Cawdor, Glamis, all As the Weïrd Women promised,

Act3Scene1.speaker: Banquo
Act3Scene1.text: and I fear Thou played’st most foully for ’t.
Act3Scene1.translation: and I fear you played most foully for it.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: Here’s our chief guest. Tonight we hold a solemn supper, sir, And I’ll request your presence.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Banquo
Act3Scene1.text: Let your Highness Command upon me, to the which my duties Are with a most indissoluble tie Forever knit.
Act3Scene1.translation: Whatever your Highness commands me to do, my duties are forever tied to you.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: Ride you this afternoon?

Act3Scene1.speaker: Banquo
Act3Scene1.text: Ay, my good lord.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: We should have else desired your good advice In this day’s council, but we’ll take tomorrow. Is ’t far you ride?

Act3Scene1.speaker: Banquo
Act3Scene1.text: As far, my lord, as will fill up the time ’Twixt this and supper.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: Fail not our feast.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Banquo
Act3Scene1.text: My lord, I will not.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: We hear our bloody cousins are bestowed in England and in Ireland, not confessing their cruel parricide, filling their hearers With strange invention.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: But of that tomorrow, when therewithal we shall have cause of state craving us jointly.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: Hie you to horse. Adieu, till you return at night. Goes Fleance with you?

Act3Scene1.speaker: Banquo
Act3Scene1.text: Ay, my good lord. Our time does call upon ’s.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: I wish your horses swift and sure of foot. Farewell.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: Sirrah, a word with you. Attend those men Our pleasure?

Act3Scene1.speaker: Servant
Act3Scene1.text: They are, my lord, without the palace gate.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: Bring them before us.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: Our fears in Banquo stick deep, and in his royalty of nature reigns that which would be feared.
Act3Scene1.translation: I fear Banquo because he has a natural nobility that make him a threat.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: Was it not yesterday we spoke together?

Act3Scene1.speaker: Murderers
Act3Scene1.text: It was, so please your Highness.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: Well then, now Have you considered of my speeches? Know That it was he, in the times past, which held you So under fortune.

Act3Scene1.speaker: First Murderer
Act3Scene1.text: You made it known to us.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: I did so, and went further. Do you find Your patience so predominant in your nature That you can let this go?

Act3Scene1.speaker: First Murderer
Act3Scene1.text: We are men, my liege.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: Both of you Know Banquo was your enemy.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Murderers
Act3Scene1.text: True, my lord.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: So is he mine. I to your assistance do make love.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: Within this hour at most I will advise you where to plant yourselves. It must be done tonight.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Murderers
Act3Scene1.text: We are resolved, my lord.

Act3Scene1.speaker: Macbeth
Act3Scene1.text: It is concluded. Banquo, thy soul’s flight, If it find heaven, must find it out tonight.
